questions.text: A previously healthy 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painless swelling on the left side of his jaw for 2 months. It has been progressively increasing in size and is draining thick, foul-smelling fluid. He does not have fever or weight loss. He had a molar extracted around 3 months ago. Two years ago, he developed a severe hypersensitivity reaction after receiving amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 4-cm, tender, erythematous mass in the left submandibular region that has a sinus draining purulent material at its lower border. Submandibular lymphadenopathy is present. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,300/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 45 mm/h. A Gram stain of the purulent material shows gram-positive filamentous rods. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgery may be required for severe or extensive cases of actinomycosis. This includes drainage of abscesses or excision of infected sinus tracts or masses. Although surgery may eventually be necessary in this patient, it is reserved for severe cases that fail to respond to antibiotic treatment.

B) CORRECT:

While penicillin is the first-line treatment for patients with actinomycosis, it is contraindicated in patients who have previously developed a severe allergic reaction following the administration of a penicillin derivative (amoxicillin in this case). Recommended alternative treatment options include doxycycline.

Actinomyces bacteria are part of the normal oral flora; however, poor dental hygiene and oral surgery predispose individuals to infection with Actinomyces.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the treatment of choice for nocardiosis, an infection with Nocardia, which also presents with gram-positive, filamentous rods on Gram stain. However, subcutaneous abscesses in nocardiosis usually arise from contaminated skin wounds (e.g., on the extremities of agricultural workers), rather than after oral surgery, since Nocardia are not commensals in the oral cavity as Actinomyces, but are found in the soil. Also, nocardiosis is much more common in severely immunocompromised patients. Actinomyces infection is not covered by TMP-SMX.

D) INCORRECT:

While penicillin is the first-line treatment for patients with actinomycosis, it is contraindicated in patients who have previously developed a severe allergic reaction following the administration of a penicillin derivate (amoxicillin in this case).

E) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin may be administered to patients with skin infections because it covers many gram-positive cocci, including streptococci and staphylococci. In many cases, it is a good alternative for patients with a penicillin allergy. However, it does not cover Actinomyces and is therefore not an appropriate alternative for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's recent history of oral surgery and a slowly progressive painless mass and purulent draining in the submandibular region are suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The finding of gram-positive rods with filaments is consistent with Actinomyces bacteria. It is important to consider this patient's history of allergic reaction to amoxicillin when deciding on the most appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painless swelling on the left side of his jaw for 2 months. It has been progressively increasing in size and is draining thick, foul-smelling fluid. He had a molar extracted 3 months ago. Examination shows a 4-cm, tender, erythematous mass in the left submandibular region with purulent drainage. There is submandibular lymphadenopathy. A culture of the purulent material shows catalase-negative, gram-positive filamentous rods that do not stain with carbol fuchsin. Which of the following is the most likely infectious pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucor irregularis is a cause of mucormycosis, a rare fungal sinusitis in immunocompromised patients. Mucor species are fungi and appear microscopically as broad, nonseptate hyphae with characteristic wide-angle branching. Although it is rapidly progressive and may affect the face, it typically presents with sinus infiltration in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis or neutropenia, not recent oral surgery.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Acinetobacter baumannii is an aerobic bacteria that causes severe infections, especially in burns or nosocomial infections. It is rod-shaped like the bacteria in this patient, but it is also gram-negative and catalase-positive. Acinetobacter species are highly resistant, found in soil, and are not associated with recent oral surgery.

C) CORRECT:

Actinomyces israelii is a gram-positive, non-acid fast, rod-shaped anaerobe and part of normal oral flora. It causes cervical actinomycosis, which typically presents as a progressively enlarging mandibular nodule after oral surgery, as in this patient. The nodules can develop into purulent draining fistulae, which contain Actinomyces in characteristic yellow “sulfur” granules. The term “sulfur granules” reflects their yellow color, not their composition. Penicillin is the drug of choice for patients with actinomycosis. Surgical resection is indicated for patients who do not respond to antibiotic treatment.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an oral tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Two Actinomyces filament conglomerates (drusen) are visible (indicated by white dashed outlines). Filaments can also be seen protruding radially and branching out of the conglomerate (examples indicated by yellow arrowheads). The drusen are surrounded by an infiltrate of neutrophils (examples indicated by red arrowheads).

Actinomyces are commonly found in nasal and pharyngeal tissue (e.g., tonsils) and their presence has no clinical significance unless accompanied by certain clinical findings (e.g., abscess formation, tissue fibrosis, or a tissue mass mimicking a tumor) and Actinomyces drusen.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is an alpha-hemolytic diplococcus that is an important cause of pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. It is gram-positive and catalase-negative like this patient's bacteria, but it is not filamentous and does not typically cause cutaneous infections. It colonizes the nasopharynx but does not present as a purulent facial nodule after oral surgery.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Streptococcus (Gram stain)

The chains of bluish-purple (gram positive) cocci seen on this Gram stain are characteristic of the genus Streptococcus.

E) INCORRECT:

Nocardia asteroides is a gram-positive filamentous bacteria that can cause cutaneous infections, as in this patient. However, it is also aerobic and weakly acid-fast and would therefore stain with carbol fuchsin. It would not be associated with recent oral surgery as in this patient, but with outdoor exposure, as it is found in soil. Nocardia classically presents with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised patients.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bacteria in blood culture (Kinyoun stain)

Clusters of branching, filamentous rods are concentrated in the center.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of anorexia, weight loss, and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum with yellow granules. Four months ago he was treated for gingivitis. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows crackles over the right upper lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows a solitary nodule and one cavitary lesion in the right upper lung field. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen from the nodule obtained via CT-guided biopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Penicillin G is the treatment of choice for thoracic actinomycosis. This patient's history of gingivitis followed by chronic cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis associated with yellow granules raises suspicion for Actinomyces israelii infection; the photomicrograph of the biopsy confirms this. Typical treatment is intravenous penicillin given for 2–6 weeks followed by an oral penicillin formulation for 6–12 months. In patients with a penicillin allergy, doxycycline or clindamycin may be used as an alternative.

B) INCORRECT:

Cisplatin and paclitaxel are chemotherapeutic agents used to treat non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). NSCLC can manifest as a cavitary lung lesion with anorexia, cough, and hemoptysis, but tissue biopsy, the gold standard for cancer diagnosis, would show neoplastic cells rather than the Actinomyces israelii found in this biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used to treat nocardiosis. Nocardia asteroides infection may manifest as a chronic cough, and a chest x-ray can demonstrate solitary nodules. However, this infection is highly uncommon in immunocompetent patients. Also, on microscopy, N. asteroides appears as gram-positive, weakly acid-fast, branching rod-shaped bacteria.

D) INCORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol constitute a multidrug regimen used to treat pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, pulmonary TB also manifests with weight loss, chronic cough, and hemoptysis. An apical pulmonary cavitation is typical as well. The biopsy specimen from this patient's lesion, however, is not consistent with M. tuberculosis, an acid-fast bacillus that classically causes caseous necrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole is used to treat fungal infections such as blastomycosis or allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Individuals with these conditions may present similarly to this patient, with chronic cough and hemoptysis. A chest x-ray may also demonstrate cavitary lesions. However, the histological image does not show fungal cells, and such fungal infections are most common in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS or ongoing chemotherapy), which is inconsistent with this patient's history.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows a central colony of Actinomyces (sulfur granule) with delicate filamentous bacilli at the periphery of the granule.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports a 4-week history of a firm, swollen jaw mass and a 2-day history of drainage from the involved area. He states that he has no significant pain, no systemic symptoms, or any prior trauma or bites in the area.
On examination, he is afebrile. Oral examination reveals multiple broken teeth. He has a reddish, purple, very firm 4-cm lesion just above the angle of his right jaw. A 3-mm open sinus tract is draining seropurulent material. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable. Swabs of the drainage are sent and reveal no growth.
A preliminary report from a punch biopsy shows inflammation, but no evidence of neoplastic disease.
Infection with which one of the following organisms is most likely to have caused this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin and soft-tissue infections with Mycobacterium abscessus can cause sinus tract formation, but the firm mass and the location would be atypical.

B) CORRECT:

Actinomyces israelii and other Actinomyces species normally colonize the oral cavity but can be found in the lower gastrointestinal tract as well. Invasion of these organisms into tissue causes actinomycosis. The lesions are characterized by mass-like, woody inflammation, leading them to be mistaken for neoplastic disease; they develop slowly, have a blue or reddish appearance, and are usually not painful. Once invasive, the organism does not respect tissue planes and spreads contiguously, often leading to sinus tract formation. The most common location for actinomycosis is oral cervicofacial disease, although pulmonary and abdominopelvic disease is well described.

Growth of the organism requires strict anaerobic culture conditions; therefore, laboratory diagnosis can be missed. Biopsy specimens show sulfur granules; the organism can be visualized with Gram’s or silver staining. Actinomyces species are exquisitely susceptible to penicillin, obviating the need for surgical resection.

Key learning point: The most likely organism to lead to a subacute presentation of a submandibular cervicofacial mass lesion with a draining sinus tract is Actinomyces species.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant infection with viridans streptococci would most commonly cause systemic illness, hot abscesses, and a more acute condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Significant infection with Staphylococcus aureus would most commonly cause systemic illness, hot abscesses, and a more acute condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Significant infection with Fusobacterium necrophorum would most commonly cause systemic illness, hot abscesses, and a more acute condition.
